loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married man living with his wife and two school-age children. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as a home electrician for the past 13 years. He also provides his customers with sanitary services. He works on a freelance basis.  From time to time, he gets help from a part-timer in order to accomplish the work and satisfy his customers' needs. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase a mini van to expand his business into other areas and be able to serve a wider range of clientele; he feels positive about his business prospects for the coming years.

loans.use: to purchase a mini van

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Um is a businesswoman who earns a living by planting crops as well as selling some fresh fish and other items in her community. She can make around $2.7 a day to cover the whole family’s needs. Her husband works as a policeman and he has a set salary every month. They are blessed with three children who study in the local school in the Baray district of Kompomg Tom Province. 

She has had great success growing crops and she is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. The coming rainfall is good for her crop. However, Um doesn’t have capital yet to use on her farm. So she is looking for a loan to use toward purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, a plowing machine and seeds for planting.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a plowing machine and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Moussodjeton 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe MOUSSODJETON 1  est composé  de femmes mariées du village de DJALAKORO  de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du fonio et du haricot.  Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel de TENIMA, qui est la première debout à gauche avec une écharpe bleu, sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide, de haricot, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 15000 à 65000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Moussodjeton 1 group is made up of married women from the village of Djalakoro in San, which lies in the Ségou region (the Republic of Mali's fourth administrative region). They live in traditional families, average 34 years of age with at least five children each. They grow groundnut, fonio and beans. With a view to making their farming activities profitable, the group members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program two years ago. Having repaid their previous loans without difficulty, they are now on their second farming loan.

Tenima, who is standing on the left of the photo and wearing a blue scarf, is going to use her loan to buy a sufficient quantity of groundnut and bean seeds, as well as small equipment and agricultural inputs at the large market in San. After the rainy season, the crops are stocked for a certain period of time in order for them to gain value before being sold at the large market in Kimparana and the surrounding markets, on a retail basis (but often wholesale too), for cash to a customer base coming generally from large towns. 

The group members are expecting to make a profit of 15,000 to 65,000FCFA each once their produce has been sold; this will be used to repay interest on their loans and cover household running costs.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Moussodjeton  2 Group

texts.fr:
MOUSSODJETON 2 est un regroupement  de femmes mariées du village de DJALAKORO,  de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 43 ans et au moins 8 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du fonio et du sésame.  Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième  prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel de BINTA, qui est  la deuxième debout à droite avec une écharpe verte, sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences de sésame et de fonio,  payer les frais de labours,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles,  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN  et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 13000 à 90.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes  de la famille.
texts.en:
Moussodjeton 2 is a group of married women from the village of Djalakoro, part of San in the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and are on average 43 years old with at least eight children.

They grow peanuts, fonio (Western Africa cereal) and sesame. To make their farms profitable, the group members decided three years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. After successfully repaying previous loans, they are on their third agricultural loan.

Binta, the second person from the right wearing a green scarf, will use her portion of the loan to buy sufficient quantities of fonio and sesame seeds, pay plowing costs, and buy small equipment and agricultural inputs at the general market in San.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value gain value before being resold at the general market in SAN and in surrounding markets, retail (often in bulk), in cash to customers usually from large cities.

After selling their agricultural products each group member hopes to achieve profits between 13,000 and 90,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 52-year-old married man living with his wife. He is from Lebanon. He is an experienced construction worker. He has been involved in the construction field for the past 31 years. In 1985, he started to work independently, sticking with multiple construction projects. Because of his large experience, there are lots of customers and construction entrepreneurs asking for his services. So, he had to hire three part-time employees in order to get all the work done.  

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to replace his old van with a new one. He says that the new van will allow him to facilitate his transportation directly to the projects where he works, especially with the heavy equipment that he carries. In the future, he looks forward to working on bigger projects.

loans.use: to replace his old van with a new one.

loans.name: Panar's Group

texts.en:
Panar is the leader of this group. She is 56 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband she has raised a son. The son is 22 years old, he is engaged in farming.

In order to earn money to meet their daily needs the family breeds cattle. They resell cattle at the higher price after fattening them. Panar also makes additional money by selling dairy products. In this way she earns an additional 3000 soms per month. 

Panar applied for the loan because she needs additional funds for purchasing a calf. In the future Panar wants to improve the family's living conditions. She will be happy to see her son get married. 

---Where Did This Loan Come From?---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.Kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team-Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://Kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim is 31 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than ten years. She sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier and local fishermen. 

She is married to Sy, 41, who works as a primary teacher in the Baray district. He gets a proper salary each month. 

This is the rainy season and the rain is falling down almost every day, so it is a good time to start planting her rice crop but she doesn’t have immediate cash to do that. So Kim is requesting a Kiva loan to purchase fertilizers, insecticides and seeds, and she will use the rest of the loan to pay for plowing costs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds and to pay for plowing costs.

loans.name: Moussodjeton  3 Group

texts.fr:
MOUSSODJETON 3  est un regroupement  de six femmes mariées du village de DJALAKORO  de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 29 ans et au moins 3 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième  prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel  de ADA, qui est la présidente du groupe et qui est la première debout à gauche avec une écharpe bleu,  sera utilisé pour acheter, de la semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, la récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de SAN et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 17000 à 70000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et  les  dépenses  courantes  de la famille.
texts.en: MOUSSODJETON 3 is a group of six married women from the village of DJALAKORO in the SAN region of SÉGOU, the fourth largest administrative region of Mali.  They live in traditional families.  Their average age is 29 and they have an average of at least 3 children.  They cultivate peanuts.  With the goal of making their agricultural business profitable, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program three years ago.  After fully repaying their prior loans, they are on their third loan. The current loan for ADA, who is the president of the group and the first person standing on the left with the blue scarf, will be used to buy peanut seeds, small equipment, and inputs for cultivation, at the main market in SAN.  After the rainy season, the harvest is stored for a certain time so that it has value, before being sold at the main market of SAN and at other nearby markets, at retail (often at wholesale), in cash, to customers who usually come from large cities.  The members of the group expect to each make, after the distribution and sale of their agricultural products, a profit of 17000 to 70000 FCFA, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and household expenses.

loans.use: to purchase inputs, seeds, and small equipment.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a father of five aged between 16 and three years. He has been in farming in Litein in South Rift Kenya for 12 years. His produce of milk and tea are sold locally. 

Daniel has requested a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He believes the income generated will pay for the education of his children. This is Daniel's second loan with Juhudi Kilimo. He hopes the business will grow significantly. 

Daniel says poor markets for farm produce are the greatest farming challenge.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James has been operating a taxi business in the town of Naivasha for the last three years. He is 33 years old and married to Irene. They have two children. 

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by his friend who is also a KADET client; this will be his second loan. He paid his previous loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) well and in good time. He plans to use this loan for servicing his motorbike and also to start a poultry rearing project. 

In the future, James hopes to own a Nissan Matatu (a van).

loans.use: to service his motorbike and to start a poultry rearing project.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is a resident farmer in Litein town in South Rift Kenya and has been in farming for 12 years. He is married with one child aged five. His farm produces tea and milk with the latter sold to Brookside Dairies. 

Benard has requested a loan of 55,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the business will improve his family's standard of living and help educate his child. 

Benard says dealing with poor markets for farm products is a great challenge.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a sugar cane squeezer machine.

loans.name: Djekafoton 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe DJEKAFOTON 1 est composé de femmes mariées du village de DAKOURA  de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 47 ans  et au moins 9 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du mil et du gombo.  Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  le  prêt précédent, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel  de BINTOU, la première assise à gauche, en T-shirt rouge, sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide  des frais de labour de sarclage  des petits matériels et des intrants  agricoles pour la culture, au grand marché de SAN ville. Après l’hivernage, la récolte  sera stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de SAN  et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 18000 à 40 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en: The DJEKAFOTON 1 group consists of married women from the village of DAKOURA in the SAN region of SEGOU, the fourth largest administrative region of Mali.  They live in traditional families. Their average age is 47 and they have at least 9 children.  They cultivate peanuts, millet, and okra.  In order to make their farms profitable, the members of the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program two years ago.  After fully repaying their prior loan, they are on their second loan.  The current loan for BINTOU, the first person seated at the left, in a red t-shirt, will be used to pay for a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, labor costs of plowing, small equipment, and agricultural inputs for cultivation, at the main market in city of SAN.  After the rainy season, the harvest will be stored for a certain period of time so that it has value before being sold at the main market of SAN and at other nearby markets. Sales are retail (often wholesale), in cash, to customers who usually come from large cities.  The members of the group intend to each make, after the distribution and sale of their agricultural products, a profit of 18000 to 40000 FCFA  which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and household expenses.

loans.use: to buy inputs, seeds, small equipment, and to pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is 35 and a mother of five children. She is married to Vincent. Saumu has been running a food kiosk in Shanzu, Mombasa for the last three years. 

This marks her second loan from KADET Ltd. She plans to renovate her business premises. The anticipated profits will be used in the expansion of her business. Her dream is to own a big hotel.

loans.use: to renovate her business premises

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy nail polish, hair products and blow dryers.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Kacerere Women's Group B

texts.en:
40-year-old Catherine has been in the agricultural business for close to 15 years now. 

Agriculture has been Uganda's economic backbone since the early sixties and for many Ugandans it is their premier source of livelihood. Catherine, who is happily married with 6 kids, says she has no regrets as to why she decided to bear a hand in this business venture. By and large, she says the business where she mostly grows and sells bananas and cassava has been profitable.Through the 15 years, she has learnt a lot about how to cultivate and harvest high-grade bananas and cassava.

She has also learnt the best methods of manure application to ensure better yields. Her business, which began with the persuasion of a close friend, has grown beyond her expectations. But, she says, it has not come easy as she has had to work extremely hard in her farming gardens to ensure this comes to pass. Monthly, she says, this business generates shillings 1,600,000 in profit. 

Catherine says she is going to use this Kiva loan money to buy more land to expand her agricultural business.

loans.use: to purchase land to expand her agricultural business.

loans.name: Enkhbold

texts.en:
Mr. Enkhbold is 45 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  His two children attend a secondary school. Mr. Enkhbold is mining engineer and he works for Olon Ovoot Gold Mining company as a field operator. His family owns a plot of land and has a small family house on it. The house is small and old and since their children are growing up, they need more space and separate rooms. 

Enkhbold is building a bigger house for his family. The project was started last year and it was stopped due to lack of funding. The loan Enkhbold is asking for will be used to buy necessary building materials such as cement, sand, wood planks, windows, insulation materials, stoves and pipes for a heating system to build a new house for his family. He is planning to build a green home which will use an  electric heating system instead of the traditional coal-fired stoves. The house will be more efficient in heating costs and will not emit smoke into the air.

loans.use: To buy necessary building materials such as cement, sand, wood planks, insulation materials, and roof tiles to build a new bigger house for his family.

loans.name: Noupagagnon 1 Group

texts.fr:
NOUPAGAGNON 1  est un groupe de femmes mariées du village de Kafono   dans la préfecture de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 31 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Elles cultivent essentiellement de l’arachide. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe NOUPAGAGNON 1 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
PORTIO, qui est la présidente et la première debout à gauche en foulard vert, compte acheter, des semences d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, essentiellement en détail au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 21000 à 23000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
Noupagagnon 1 is a group of married women from the village of Kafono, part of the San prefecture in the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and are on average 31 years old with at least four children.

They mainly grow peanuts. To make their farming profitable, members of the Noupagagnon 1 group decided two years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. Having successfully repaid the previous loan, they are now on their second agricultural loan.

Portio, who is the president and is the first person standing on the right with a green scarf, wants to buy peanuts for planting, small farming equipment and agricultural inputs at the general market in Kimparana.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value before being resold at the general market in Kimparana and in surrounding markets, mainly retail for cash to customers usually from large cities.

After selling their agricultural products each member of the group hopes to achieve profits between 21,000 and 23,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds, and small farming equipment

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim is a domestic farmer who has been living in Kompong Cham Province. She normally spends most of her time in the farming business. She always uses her fertile farm to grow a few crops and her husband frequently helps in the crop-planting business. 

For more profit, Sim catches fish on the lake. 

The couple has given birth to three children. One is also employed in the farming business while the other two are still enrolled in school. 

Sim will use the loan to hire a plowing machine to plow her farmland and to purchase potato seeds, insecticides and fertilizers for her crops. With the rest, she will purchase some planks to repair her old wall.

loans.use: to hire a plowing machine to plow her farmland and to purchase potato seeds, insecticides and fertilizers for her crops.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas   has been in the mining industry for the last 13 years in Naivasha town. He is 33 years old, married to Teresia. They are blessed with four schooling children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend who is also a KADET client. This will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan amount to buy another extraction site and add more manpower.

In future, Nicholas hopes to own several extraction sites on the outskirts of Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy another extraction site and add more manpower.

loans.name: Noupagagnon Ii Group

texts.fr:
NOUPAGAGNON II  est un groupe de femmes mariées du village de KAFONO  dans l’ex cercle de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 33  ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de SORO Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  le  prêt précédent, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
ROKIA, qui est la deuxième debout à droite en boubou bleu, compte utiliser son   prêt actuel pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 14500 à 16000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en: NOUPAGAGNON II is a group of married women from the village of KAFONO, in the prefecture of SAN, Region of SÉGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in traditional families, and they average 33 years of age and have at least four children. The group members grow peanuts. Concerned about making their plantations profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. After properly repaying the previous loan, they are now on their second farm loan. ROKIA, who is standing second from the right in the photo and wearing a blue boubou, intends to use her loan to buy a sufficient amount of peanut seeds, sundry supplies and equipment, and some inputs for farming. These items are purchased at the main market of Kimparana City. Following the off-season, the harvested crops are stocked for a certain time, so that they gain value. And then they are sold retail (and often in bulk) and for cash at the main market of Kimparana and at surrounding markets. The customers generally come from large cities. After selling the produce, the group members each plan on making a profit of 14,500 to 16,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest and for covering typical family expenses.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs, seeds, and tools

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is 35 years old and married to Margaret who contributes to the family income. He has been running his business for a period of about six years with an income of about KES.11,000 a month.

This is his second loan with KADET LTD after successfully repaying the previous one. He hopes to be a leading vegetable supplier in Thika town.

loans.use: to buy cabbages, spinach and onions for sale.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
For the last seven years Daniel has been operating a shop in the Kitiri area, Ndunyu Njeru town. He is 39 years old and married to Agnes. They have one schooling child.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a staff member from KADET, located in the Ndunyu Njeru office. This will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan to add more stock of trousers and shirts.

In the future Daniel aspires to practice dairy farming in the Kariri area, Ndunyu Njeru town

loans.use: To add more stock of trousers and shirts.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 32-year-old Lebanese married man. He lives with his wife and two school-aged children. He has owned a small shop since 2009 where he sells wide variety of watches and women's accessories. He has been involved in this occupation for the past 10 years. He has taken advantage of two Kiva loans and has been an honest client, repaying on his scheduled dates. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $2000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase his store inventory. He is planning to purchase a new range of watches in styles to attract more customers and increase his sales in order to earn higher income. In the future, he is looking to further expand his business and add women's bags to sell.

loans.use: to increase his store inventory.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
For the last 12 years David has been practicing farming in the Ngondi area, Naivasha town. He is 36 years old, married to Mary, and they have five school-going children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan. He repaid his previous loan of KES 45,000 in full and in good time. He plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizers, pesticides and cater for farm labour.

In the future, David aspires to buy a pick-up vehicle for transporting farm produce to the market.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides and cater for farm labour.

loans.name: Noupagagnon Iii Group

texts.fr:
NOUPAGAGNON III est un regroupe de femmes mariées du village de KAFONO  dans la préfecture  de SAN, région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 37   ans et au moins 8 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du gombo, du haricot etc. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  le  prêt précédent, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
HAWA, debout au milieu enfant au dos, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, les frais de labour et sarclage  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles pour la culture, au grand marché de kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 24000 à 26000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
NOUPAGAGNON III is  group of married women from the village of KAFONO, in the prefecture of SAN, Region of SÉGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in traditional families with their husbands, children, and other parents. And they average 37 years of age and have at least eight children. The group members grow peanuts, okra, beans, etc. 

Concerned about making their plantations profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. After properly repaying the previous loans, they are now on their second farm loan.

HAWA, who is standing in the middle in the photo and carrying a child on her back, intends to use her loan to buy a sufficient amount of peanut seeds, to pay for plowing and weeding, and to buy sundry supplies and equipment and some inputs for farming. These items are purchased at the main market of Kimparana City. Following the off-season, the harvested crops are stocked for a certain time, so that they gain value. And then they are sold retail (and often wholesale) and for cash at the main market of Kimparana and at the surrounding markets. The customers generally come from large cities. 

After selling the produce, the group members each plan on making a profit of 24,000 to 26,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest and for covering typical family expenses.

loans.use: to buy inputs and tools and to pay for plowing

loans.name: Masika

texts.fr: La cliente Masika est entrepreneur, âgée de 48 ans, veuve, mère de 4 enfants, tous étudient. Elle est vendeuse des oignons, ails, etc. Elle s’installe dans un dépôt de vente au centre commercial agricole de Birere. Il ya 15 ans révolus qu’elle exerce cette activité. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  20 cycles avec le crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner  avec  10 sacs d’oignons, 12 sacs d’ails et le reste sera affecté dans les petits projets de la famille.  En plus, elle ambitionne scolariser ses enfants et acheter une grande parcelle pour sa famille enfin d’y construire aisément.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique.
texts.en: The customer, Masika, is an entrepreneur, who is 48 years old, a widow and mother to four children, all of whom are studying. She sells onions, garlic, etc. She has set herself up in a sales outlet at the agricultural shopping centre in Birere. She has been carrying out this activity for the past 15 years. She has, however, just completed her 20th loan cycle with Hekima. This new loan will be used to get fresh supplies: ten sacks of onions and 12 sacks of garlic; the remainder will be used for small family projects. Furthermore, her ambition is to be able to educate her children and buy a large piece of land for her family in order to build a house with ease. The customer is grateful to Hekima for its actions in favour of poor women who are unable to access classic banks.

loans.use: to buy ten sacks of onions and twelve sacks of garlic, etc

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy has been operating a boutique in Naivasha town for the last year. She is a 31-year-old lady married to Thomas, and they have two children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD  by her friend who is also a KADET client and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan to open a cosmetics shop.

In the future she hopes to expand her boutique business and also open a bakery.

loans.use: To open a cosmetics shop.

loans.name: Bolormaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Bolormaa is 42 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family owns a plot of land and a small house on it which was bought in 2005. 

Bolormaa has been running a clothing retail business since 2009 on the Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar. During past two years her working capital has increased four times. Her husband runs a taxi business using his family car, earning extra income for the family. They have two children and the elder one is a student at the National Science and Technology University. The kids are grown up and need more space and separate rooms. 

The house where they live is 15 square meters and they live quite squashed. Bolormaa is planning to build an extension to the house, making separate rooms for her kids. The loan she is taking will be used to buy necessary building materials and to build the extension to the house.

loans.use: To buy necessary building materials and build an extension to the house, making separate rooms for her children.

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander has been in the mining business for the last 25 years in Naivasha  town. He is 49 years old, married to Stella Nduta. They are blessed with four schooling children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend who is also a KADET client. This will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan amount to buy another extraction site and add more manpower. 

In future, Alexander hopes to own several extraction sites on the outskirts of Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy another extraction site and add more manpower.

loans.name: Tieng

texts.en: Tieng resides in Kompong Cham Province. To earn a living, she plants rice crops on her farmland. On average, she could make about $1.50 profit a day to use for financial expenses. She shares some responsibilities with Tieng, her husband, who is a tobacconist in the mobile place and he earns around US $2 each day. They have been married for many years and they are blessed with a kid who is attending primary school and lives under their income. To expand her husband's business, Tieng would like to borrow funds provided by leaders on Kiva to assist her husband torward buying more tobacco to store for future sale.

loans.use: to buy more tobacco to store for future sale.

loans.name: Noupagagnon Iv Group

texts.fr:
NOUPAGAGNON IV  est un regroupe de femmes mariées du village de KAFONO  dans la préfecture de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 39   ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du gombo, du haricot.  
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  le  prêt précédent, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
KORO, en tenue bleu au milieu,  compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter,  des semences d’arachide, les frais de labour et sarclage  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles pour la culture, au grand marché de kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 26000 à 29000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
NOUPAGAGNON IV is a group of married women from the village of KAFONO, in the prefecture of SAN, Region of SÉGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in traditional families with their husbands, children, and other parents. And they average 39 years of age and have at least six children. The group members grow peanuts, okra, beans, etc.

Concerned about making their plantations profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. After properly repaying the previous loans, they are now on their second farm loan.

KORO, who is standing in the middle in the photo and dressed in blue, intends to use her loan to buy a sufficient amount of peanut seeds, to pay for plowing and weeding, and to buy sundry supplies and equipment and some inputs for farming. These items are purchased at the main market of Kimparana City. Following the off-season, the harvested crops are stocked for a certain time, so that they gain value. And then they are sold retail (and often in bulk) and for cash at the main market of Kimparana and at the surrounding markets. The customers generally come from large cities.

After selling the produce, the group members each plan on making a profit of 26,000 to 29,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest and for covering typical family expenses.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs, seeds, and tools and to pay for plowing

loans.name: Munavar

texts.en:
Munavar is a widow with two children. She is a hardworking and responsible woman. For five years, Munavar has been running a food stall, selling her products in a local market called Ganj. She sells sugar, bread, chocolate, sweets, and other items. Munavar is the only breadwinner in the family and she wants to provide for her children’s needs.  

Munavar is requesting a loan of 3,000 USD to purchase merchandise for her store. She would like to expand her business and improve the living conditions of her family.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy food items to sell

loans.name: Feisal

texts.en:
Feisal is 37 years old and married to Ann. The couple has one child. For the past 14 years, Feisal has operated a butcher shop.

Feisal was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend who is also a client. This will be his second loan. He repaid a previous loan of 50,000 KES in full and in good time. Feisal plans to use his loan to buy ten goats for slaughter and add to the stock of meat in his butcher shop.

In the future, Feisal hopes to expand his butcher shop and add a restaurant.

loans.use: to buy ten goats for slaughter and to add to his stock of meat

loans.name: Mona

texts.en:
Mona is 38 years old and married to Ziad who works as a dustman at one the governmental entities. They have five children, all under the age of 18 years old.

Despite losing her right hand in a car accident a while ago, Mona wanted to do something to help her husband in supporting their family, since his salary is not enough to do so. 

Four years ago, Mona started a retailing business at their house, selling home products such as cups, plates, pans, etc. and it has been going very well. Now Mona is applying for loan to increase her storage of products so she can increase her profit and open a home products shop.

loans.use: To buy more home products for her retail business.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta is 41 years old and married with three children. She lives in the Philippines. Violeta has a business raising pigs and she earns approximately 5,000 PHP each month.

Violeta has been a member of PMPC for two years. She is requesting a loan to purchase sacks of pig feed. In the future, Violeta hopes to use the extra money from her business for her children’s education.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed

loans.name: Wolale 1 Group

texts.fr:
WOLALE 1 est un regroupement de femmes  toutes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 48  ans et au moins 9  enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide,  du fonio et du sésame. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième  prêt de campagne.
DOUNABA, la plus grande, debout en deuxième position à droite, en boubou bleu et collier au cou, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences de sésame et de fonio, des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles  pour la culture,  au grand marché de SAN  ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN, de DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 13000 à 81000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en: WOLALE 1 is a group of married women from the village of CINZARA, in the prefecture of SAN, Region of SÉGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in traditional families, and they average 48 years of age and have at least nine children. The group members grow peanuts, fonio (a kind of millet), and sesame. Concerned about making their plantations profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After properly repaying the previous loans, they are now on their third farm loan. DOUNABA (the tallest one in the photo, second from the right, and wearing a blue boubou and a necklace), intends to use her loan to buy a sufficient amount of sesame and fonio seeds, sundry supplies and equipment, and some inputs for farming. These items are purchased at the main market of SAN City. Following the off-season, the harvested crops are stocked for a certain time, so that they gain value. And then they are sold retail (and often in bulk) and for cash at the main markets of SAN and DAH and at the surrounding markets. The customers generally come from large cities. After selling the produce, the group members each plan on making a profit of 13,000 to 81,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest and for covering typical family expenses.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs, seeds, and tools

loans.name: Eugenie

texts.en:
Eugenie is 35 years old and has six children between the ages of 17 and 35. For the past four years, she has been selling foodstuffs. Her business is doing well and has enabled her to feed and educate her family. 

Eugenie is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise to sell in order to increase her profit. In the future, she plans to buy a cow from which she hopes to get milk.

loans.use: to buy foodstuff and items to sell

loans.name: Janyl's Group

texts.en:
Janyl is the leader of this group. She is 26 years old and married to a mechanic. Together they are bringing up two daughters, both of whom are preschool age (under seven). Five years ago, Janyl saved 15,000 KGS and used it to purchase livestock. She currently breeds livestock that she resells at a higher price after fattening. In this way, she earns additional money to meet her family's needs.  

Janyl is requesting a loan to purchase more livestock animals for breeding. She hopes that her loan will help her to develop her business. In the future, Janyl wants to give her children a good education.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last seven years. She is  32 years old, single,  and the mother of three children. 

She got to know about KADET LTD through various marketing activities carried out by KADET staff in Ndunyu Njeru town. This will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizers, seedlings and cater for labor.

In future, Pauline hopes to increase farm production by practicing large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seedlings and cater for labour.

loans.name: Wolale 2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE 2 est constitué de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 48  ans et au moins 9  enfants.
Elles cultivent du fonio et du sésame. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième  prêt de campagne.
HAWA, première personne assise vers la gauche, en noir,  compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de fonio, des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles  pour la culture,  au grand marché de SAN  ville. Après l’hivernage, la récolte est  stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de SAN, de DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 11500 à 65.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wolale 2 group is made up of married women from the village of Cinzara in the prefecture of San, which lies in Ségou, the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They live in traditional families, average 48 years of age with at least nine children. They grow fonio or finger millet and sesame. With the aim of making their farms profitable, the group members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program three years ago. Having repaid their previous loans in full, they are now on their third farming loan.

Hawa, the first person sitting towards the left of the photo and wearing black, is planning to use her loan to buy a sufficient amount of fonio seeds, small equipment and agricultural imputs to aid growth, at the large market in the town of San. After the rainy season the crop is stocked for a certain amount of time so that it will gain value before being sold at the large markets in San and Dah as well as in the surrounding markets, on a retail basis (but often wholesale), for cash to a customer base coming generally from large towns.

The group members are expecting each to make a profit of between 11,500 and 65,0000FCFA after selling their farming produce, and this will be used for the repayment of their loan interest and household running costs.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural inputs, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Sros

texts.en:
Sros, 22 years old, is a factory worker. Her husband is a motor taxi driver. They have one child and he is 4 years old. 

Their gross income is $28 per day. Almost 80% of the income is from her husband. Every month, she has to spend $50 on food and $5 on electricity. 

She would like to a request loan of $500 to buy a new motorcycle for her husband to continue his career as motor taxi driver because the old one is not working properly. 

In the future she plans to start a tailor shop so that she can stay home and take care of her children and raise animals.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle for her husband 's motor taxi business.

loans.name: Oeur

texts.en: From Siem Reap Province, Mrs. Oeur, 47, has been producing fish-paste for many years. She is a single mother who now lives in a small house with two single children: one works in the fishing business and the other one sells many kinds of goods at home.  She has three other children who are married and live in a separate house. Mrs. Oeur is seeking a loan from Kiva to use as capital to buy more fish to produce fish-paste for sale and to support her child in the merchandise business. Mrs. Oeur is pictured in front her daughter’s store.

loans.use: to buy more fish to produce fish-paste for sale and to support her child in the merchandise business.

loans.name: Wolale Bamana 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE BAMANA 1  fait partie de l’association WOLALE des femmes du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles sont toutes mariées et  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec en moyenne 48  ans et au moins 9  enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du fonio et du sésame.  Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de SORO Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième  prêt de campagne.
MARTHE, qui est la présidente du groupe et la première debout à gauche avec une écharpe bleu, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences de fonio  et d’arachide,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles  pour la culture, exclusivement  au grand marché de SAN  ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et KIMPARANA  et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe  comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 36000 à 39000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wolale Bamana 1 group is part of the Wolale association of women from the village of Cinzara in the San prefecture of the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are all married and live in traditional extended families and are on average 48 years old with at least nine children.

They grow peanuts, fonio (a West-African cereal) and sesame. To make their farming profitable, group members decided three years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. Having successfully repaid previous loans, they are now on their third agricultural loan cycle.

Marthe, who is the group’s president and is the first person standing on the left wearing a blue scarf, wants to use her portion of the loan to buy sufficient quantities of fonio seeds and peanuts for planting, small farming equipment and agricultural inputs, exclusively from the general market in San.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value before being resold at the general market in San, Kimparana and in surrounding markets, mainly retail (often in bulk) for cash to customers usually from large cities.

After selling their agricultural products each member of the group hopes to achieve profits between 36,000 and 39,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen, 62 years old, is a farmer. She is married and has three children, 27, 26, and 20 years old. Her children are working in the factory. 

She does not make any income, but she gets support from all of her children who work in the factory. Each of them gets $10 per day. Each month, she has to spend $100 on food, $5 on electricity, $12 on their transportation to work and $15 for other expenses.  

She would like to request a loan of $1,000 to buy her son a new motorbike for his transportation to work.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for her son to commute to work.

loans.name: Pelagie

texts.en:
Pelagie  was born in 1958. She has eight children who are aged 15-30 years. Five of them are in school while the other three have accomplished school. Her husband is a farmer.

Pelagie sells sorghum and this business has enabled her to feed her family with no difficulties. She has done this business for five years. She is requesting a loan to buy more sorghum and make a locally produced non-alcoholic drink called "ubushera". She plans to renovate her house with the profits she hopes to make.

loans.use: to buy sorghum to make a non-alcoholic drink called "ubushera".

loans.name: Wolale Bamana 2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE BAMANA 2 est constitué de 10 femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies  avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 47  ans et au moins 8  enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du fonio et du sésame Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après correctement remboursé  elles sont à leur troisième  prêt de campagne.
BAH, qui est debout avec une écharpe blanche sur la tête, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences de fonio d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles  pour la culture, au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et KIMPARANA  et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (très généralement), au comptant  à une clientèle composé de revendeurs et de quelques consommateurs.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 16.000 à 18000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wolale Bamana 2 group consists of ten married women from the village of Cinzara in the San prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are all married and live in traditional extended families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They are on average 47 years old with at least eight children.

They grow peanuts, fonio (a West-African cereal) and sesame. To make their farming profitable, group members decided three years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. Having successfully repaid previous loans, they are now on their third agricultural loan cycle.

Bah, who is standing and wearing a white headscarf, wants to use her portion of the loan to buy sufficient quantities of fonio seeds and peanuts for planting, small farming equipment and agricultural inputs, from the general market in San.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value before being resold at the general market in San, Kimparana and in surrounding markets, mostly retail against cash to resellers and a few consumers.

After selling their agricultural products each member of the group hopes to achieve profits between 16,000 and 18,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Ventatie

texts.en: Ventatie   is 29 years old, and she has a one-year-old child. She owns a shop in which she sells rice and soap. This business has enabled her to feed her family. She has done this business for the past two years. She needs a loan to buy foodstuffs and make more profits. She plans to save all her profits and buy a milling machine.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs.

loans.name: Enkhtuya

texts.en:
Mrs. Enkhtuya is 43 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family live in the house which they built two years ago using a loan which was taken from our MFI. The loan was successfully repaid on time. 

Mrs.Enkhtuya has been running a newspaper and grocery kiosk at the bus station for 11 years. She has gained lots of experience in running the kiosk and she works  from 6:00 in the morning till 11:00 in the evening in rotation with her elder sister. 

This time Enkhtuya is planning to build a warm garage for her family car. The warm garage is essential in Mongolia especially in wintertime when the temperature reaches minus 40 degrees Celsius at night. The loan Enkhtuya is requesting will be used to build this warm garage for her family car.

loans.use: To build a warm garage for her family car.

loans.name: Nurbibi

texts.en:
Nurbibi is a hard-working and honest woman. She is married and the loving mother of four children. Her husband works as a master and she, together with her husband, tries to provide all the needs of their children. 

Nurbibi is engaged in selling foods at the market. She sells daily used foods such as carrots, potatoes, onions, apricots, cherries, etc. Nurbibi would like to get a loan of 7,500 TJS for purchasing of foods in order to increase the assortment of her products and expand her business.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy foods for business expansion.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua cooks foods such as fufu (mashed cassava), banku (fermented maize dough), groundnut soup, okra soup and others at Ankwanda, a village near Elmina, a fishing community in Cape Coast. Efua has received junior high education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a carpenter. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. 

Her loan will be used to buy ingredients such as cassava, plantains, maize, groundnut paste and other food items to cook for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a better place.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as cassava, plantains, maize, groundnut paste and other food items.

loans.name: Violette

texts.en: Violette was born in 1987 and she has two children who are aged one and three years old. Violette owns a shop in which she sells different items such as candles, matches, sanitary pads and a few foodstuffs such as beans, sorghum, etc., and she has been doing this business for two years. This business has enabled her to meet the needs of her family. She is requesting a loan to buy more foodstuffs such as sorghum and beans. With the profits she plans to renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs for sale.

loans.name: Wolale Bamana 3 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE BAMANA 3 est formé de 10 femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de San, région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 39 ans et au moins 5  enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du fonio et du sésame.  Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
KONIMBA, qui est la première debout à gauche en robe blanchâtre, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, des semences de fonio et d’arachide,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles  pour la culture,  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 15000 à 69.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wolale Bamana 3 group consists of ten married women from the village of Cinzara in the San prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and are on average 39 years old with at least five children.

They grow peanuts, fonio (a West-African cereal) and sesame. To make their crop-farming profitable, group members decided three years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. Having successfully repaid previous loans, they are now on their third agricultural loan cycle.

Konimba, who is the first standing on the left wearing an off-white dress, wants to use her portion of the loan to buy fonio seeds and peanuts for planting, small farming equipment and agricultural inputs for crop-growing, from the general market in San.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value before being resold at the general market in San, Dah and in surrounding markets, mostly retail (often in bulk) against cash to a customer base coming from large towns.

After selling their agricultural products each member of the group hopes to achieve profits between 15,000 and 69,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: For the past two years, Araba has been selling fish, porridge and doughnuts at Elmina. She is married to a mason and has five dependents. She helps her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy ingredients to make porridge and flour to fry the doughnuts so that she can continue food production. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children. In this picture, Araba is taking out some of the fried doughnuts.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to make porridge and flour to fry doughnuts.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi sells food items such as cassava, plantains, "garden eggs" (a kind of eggplant), okra, fresh tomatoes, canned tomatoes and other items at Elmina. She is married and has six dependents. Her husband is a farmer. She has been in this trade for five years.  She helps her husband to provide the daily needs of the family. Her loan will be used to buy fresh tomatoes, onions and other items to sell. She hopes to reinvest her profit into her business.

loans.use: to buy fresh tomatoes, onions and other items to sell.

loans.name: Wolale Bamana 4 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE BAMANA 4 est constitué de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 38  ans et au moins 6  enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du fonio et du sésame. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième  prêt de campagne.
BINTOU, la troisième debout à gauche en écharpe blanche, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences de fonio, d’arachide,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles  pour la culture, au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 21000 à 22.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wolale Bamana 4 group consists of married women from the village of Cinzara in the San prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and are on average 38 years old with at least six children.

They grow peanuts, fonio (a West-African cereal) and sesame. To make their crop-farming profitable, group members decided three years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. Having successfully repaid previous loans, they are now on their third agricultural loan cycle.

Bintou, standing third from the left and wearing a white scarf, wants to use her portion of the loan to buy sufficient quantities of fonio seeds and peanuts for planting, small farming equipment and agricultural inputs for crop-growing, from the general market in San.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value before being resold at the general market in San, Dah and in surrounding markets, mostly retail (often in bulk) against cash to a customer base mainly coming from large towns.

After selling their agricultural products each member of the group hopes to achieve profits between 21,000 and 22,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Marie Chantal

texts.en: Marie Chantal is 36 years old has two children who are 4 and 13 years old. Her older child is in school while the younger is too young to attend yet. She makes a living by owning a shop where she sells different kinds of items such as salt, sorghum, cooking oil and maize. This business allows her to support her family and make sure everyone has enough to eat. She is requesting a loan to buy more items for her shop such as cooking oil, salt, beans and sorghum. She hopes to earn enough money to expand her shop in future.

loans.use: to buy more food items to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace makes a living by selling palm and palm kernel oil, soap, salt and other food items at a stall in the town of Elmina. She has received a senior high school level of education, is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. Grace has been in her current line of work for the last eight years and is committed to help her husband provide for the daily needs of their family. She has applied for a loan to buy soaps, detergent and various food items to sell to her customers. She hopes to use the profits from her business to help provide her children with a university education.

loans.use: to buy various items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Tusaidiane Group

texts.fr: La cliente Masika représentante du groupe d’affaire « Tusaidiane »,  est entrepreneur, âgée de 45 ans, mariée, mère de 5 enfants, tous étudient. Elle fait l’artisanat, la forgerie de  fabrication des braseros à travers le sol d’argile. Elle s’entraide avec son mari dans la commercialisation de ces produits. Elle étale ces braseros au long de la route, sur les différents points de vente. Signalons que ces braséros réduisent le cout de consommation de braises. D’où, sa contribution sur la conservation de l’environnement. Il ya 10 ans révolus qu’elle exerce cette activité. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  18 cycles avec le crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner  avec  la terre d’argile, 10 tôles, quelques carcasses, etc.  En plus, elle ambitionne scolariser ses enfants et construire une clôture autour de sa résidence.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire « Tusaidiane» est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en:
The client named Masika, representative of the business group called « Tusaidiane » is a 45-year-old entrepreneur, married and the mother of five children, all enrolled in school. She is an artisan, making fired brasiers using clay. She and her husband share the duty of selling the products. She sets up her brasiers alongside the road, at different sales points. Please note that these clay brasiers reduce the cost and use of charcoal, so she contributes to protecting the environment. She has been in this business for 10 years, however, she has just completed her 18th loan with Hekima. 

This new loan will serve to buy clay, 10 pieces of sheet metal, etc. She also wants to pay school fees for her children and build a fence around her property. The client thanks Hekima for working on behalf of poor women who are excluded from conventional banks. Please also note that the business group  « Tusaidiane» is made up mostly of women.

loans.use: to buy clay, 10 pieces of sheet metal, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Franco

texts.en:
Franco is  36 years old and this gentleman is from Kakamega, one of Kenya’s largest counties. He is married to Alice who is a business lady and they have four children under their care.

Franco operates a retail shop in Kakamega Town and has been running this business for the  last 17 years. He makes a monthly income of KES. 19,500. He has been a KADET  client for a long time and he is taking his sixth loan of KES. 80,000 which he will use to buy a new stock of items for sale like cooking fat, sugar, baking flour and many other everyday items as per customer request and demand.

He will use the anticipated profits to pay back the loan and plough back into business. His dream is to one day open a wholesale shop, supplying stock to other retailers within his locality.

loans.use: To buy daily use products for his retail shop.

loans.name: Adjoa Felicia

texts.en: Adjoa sells cosmetics, panties and other items at Elmina. Adjoa has received senior high education. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a fisherman. She has been selling cosmetics, panties and other items for five years. She helps to pay the utility bills and other household expenses. Her loan will be used to buy cosmetics and panties. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a shop.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy cosmetics and panties.

loans.name: Wolale Bamana 5 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE BAMANA 5 est compose de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 39  ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du fonio et du sésame. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
BATOMA, la première à droite en écharpe jaune, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, des semences de fonio d’arachide  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles  pour la culture, au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 18000 à 75.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wolale Bamana 5 group consists of married women from the village of Cinzara in the San prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and are on average 39 years old with at least six children.

They grow peanuts, fonio (a West-African cereal) and sesame. To make their crop-farming profitable, group members decided three years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. Having successfully repaid previous loans, they are now on their third agricultural loan cycle.

Batoma, first on the right with a yellow scarf, wants to use her portion of the loan to buy fonio seeds and peanuts for planting, small farming equipment and agricultural inputs for crop-growing, from the general market in San.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value before being resold at the general market in San, Dah and in surrounding markets, retail (often in bulk) against cash mainly to customers coming from large towns.

After selling their agricultural products each member of the group hopes to achieve profits between 18,000 and 75,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.
