loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Aisuluu's Group

texts.en:
Aisuluu is the leader of this group. She is 43 and married to a private driver. Together with her husband she's bringing up two sons; the first son studies at school and the second is preschool age (under seven). Aisuluu works as an office manager in a rural consultant company. She also breeds poultry to earn additional money. She started this business fifteen years ago and her monthly profit from this activity is 1500 soms. 

Aisuluu applied for the loan because she needs additional funds for purchasing building materials (schist and cement) to start house construction.  In the future she wants to give both her sons a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase building materials to build a house.

loans.name: Wolale Bamana 6 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE BAMANA 6 est constitué de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA, préfecture de SAN, région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 42  ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du fonio et du sésame. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts, elles sont à leur troisième  prêt de campagne.
BAH, qui est debout au milieu,  compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences de fonio d’arachide  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles  pour la culture, au grand marché de SAN  ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 19.500à 22.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en: The group WOLALE BAMANA 6 is composed of married women from the village of CINZARA, in the prefecture of SAN, Region of SÉGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in traditional families with their husbands, children, and other parents. And they average 42 years of age and have at least four children. The group members grow peanuts, fonio (a kind of millet), and sesame. Concerned about making their plantations profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After properly repaying the previous loans, they are now on their third farm loan. BAH, who is standing in the middle in the photo, intends to use her loan to buy a sufficient amount of peanut and fonio seeds, sundry supplies and equipment, and some inputs for farming. These items are purchased at the main market of SAN City. Following the off-season, the harvested crops are stocked for a certain time, so that they gain value. And then they are sold retail (and often in bulk) and for cash at the main markets of SAN and DAH and at surrounding markets. The customers generally come from large cities. After selling the produce, the group members each plan on making a profit of 19,500 to 22,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest and for covering typical family expenses.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs, seeds, and tools

loans.name: Kesue

texts.en:
Kesue is 27 years old, married, and lives with his wife and three children. He grows seasonal crops on his land, working on the crops until it is time to harvest them. 

In addition, for extra income he raises goats. This is his third loan from KADET LTD. He will buy seeds and fertilizers for his land with this loan.

He hopes to make a profit and use it to invest in another business. He is an assiduous man who can do more if funded.

loans.use: buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi is a fishmonger at Elmina, a fishing community in Cape Coast. She is divorced and has two children. Her income is used to see to the up-keep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy fresh fish to smoke. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to plough back into her business.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish to smoke.

loans.name: Wolale  Marakasso 1 Group

texts.fr:
WOLALE MARAKASSO 1 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent  exclusivement du sésame.  Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans  et sont à leur deuxième  prêt de campagne. KADIA, la première assise à droite avec une écharpe noire, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, de la semence de sésame, des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, la récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de SAN, de DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 29000 à 30000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
Wolale Marakasso 1 is a group of married women from the village of Cinzara in the San prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional extended families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They are on average 38 years old with at least five children.

They grow exclusively sesame. To make their crop-farming profitable, group members decided two years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. Having successfully repaid previous loans, they are now on their second agricultural loan cycle.

Kadia, first sitting on the right with a black scarf, wants to use her portion of the loan to buy sesame seeds, small farming equipment and agricultural inputs at the general market in San.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value before being resold at the general market in San, Dah and in surrounding markets, retail (often in bulk) against cash mainly to customers coming from large towns.

After selling their agricultural products each member of the group hopes to achieve profits between 29,000 and 30,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is a widow and has 2 children. She sells shea butter, powder and ointment at a village called Ankwanda near Elmina, which she has done for 20 years. Ama uses her income to pay rent and other expenses. Ama will use the loan to purchase shea butter, powder and other things to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to build a cosmetics shop.

loans.use: to purchase shea butter, powder and other things to sell

loans.name: Suhad

texts.en:
Suhad is a 30-year-old mother for five children; she has been married to Amjad, a school bus driver, for 11 years now. 

Four years ago Suhad started selling home products at her house; she sells items such as melamine plates, glasses, pans, etc. She has gained her neighbors' and customers' trust. 

Now Suhad is applying for a loan to raise her capital and to buy more products so she can make more profit from selling them.

loans.use: To buy more home products to sell.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa sells boodo at Elmina. Boodo is made from flour, sugar, maize and other ingredients. The process of cooking boodo is by baking. As you can see in this picture, Adjoa has filled the oven with boodo to bake. 

She wishes to expand her business so she needs a loan to buy maize, flour and other things to bake for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: to buy maize, flour and other things to bake for sale

loans.name: Wolale Marakasso 2 Group

texts.fr:
WOLALE MARAKASSO 2 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture  de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies  avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 43 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes cultivent  exclusivement du sésame.  Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso  il y a deux ans  d’ où leur deuxième  prêt de campagne et  KADIA, la première debout à droite avec une écharpe, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles  pour la culture,  au grand marché de SAN  ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 21000 à 93 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
Wolale Marakasso 2 is a group of married women from the village of Cinzara in the San prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional extended families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They are on average 43 years old with at least four children.

This group of women grow exclusively sesame. To make their crop-farming profitable, group members decided two years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. They are now on their second agricultural loan cycle.

Kadia, first standing on the right with a scarf, wants to use her portion of the loan to buy a sufficient quantity of seeds, small farming equipment and agricultural inputs for crop-growing, at the general market in the town of San.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value before being resold at the general market in San, Dah and in surrounding markets, retail (often in bulk) against cash mainly to customers coming from large towns.

After selling their agricultural products each member of the group hopes to achieve profits between 21,000 and 93,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seeds and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more items to sell and increase his profit

They grow exclusively sesame. To make their crop-farming profitable, group members decided two years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. They are now on their second agricultural loan cycle.

Rokia, sitting in the center, wants to use her portion of the loan to buy a sufficient quantity of seeds, small farming equipment and agricultural inputs for crop-growing, at the general market in the town of San.

After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while so that they can gain value before being resold at the general market in San, Dah and in surrounding markets, retail (often in bulk) against cash mainly to customers coming from large towns.

After selling their agricultural products each member of the group hopes to achieve profits between 15,000 and 68,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay loan interests and cover ongoing family expenses.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase of more crates of hard and soft alcoholic beverages to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase 4 calves and fodder

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 28 years old, married, and has a 7-year-old son. He has been selling secondhand shoes for 14 years. George plans to use his loan to purchase more shoes for his business. He especially wants to purchase more men’s shoes as they sell really fast. 

This is George’s first loan. He wants to use the profits from his business to open a permanent shop. George dreams of running a prominent secondhand shoe business. He describes himself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: to purchase more secondhand shoes for his business

loans.name: Wolale Marakasso 4 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE MARAKASSO 4  est composé de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans et au moins 6  enfants.
Elles cultivent  exclusivement du sésame.  Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans d’ ou leur deuxième  prêt de campagne et  PORTIO, qui est la deuxième femmes  assise  à gauche en T-shirt jaune, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles au grand marché de SAN  ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN  et DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe  comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 19000 à 41000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en: The Wolale Marakasso 4 group is made up of married women from the village of Cinzara in the San region of Segou, the fourth largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They live in traditional families and are all around 39 years old with at least 6 children each. They specialise in the cultivation of sesame. In order to generate higher profits from their agricultural activities, the group members decided to seek a loan from Soro Yiriwaso two years ago, and are seeking their second from them now. Portio- the second lady from the right sitting down, and wearing a yellow T-shirt- aims to use her loan to purchase a sufficient quantity of seeds, small tools and agricultural inputs from the large town market at San. Once the rainy season has passed, the harvest is stored for a while so that it rises in value before being sold at the large town markets of San and Dah and in the neighbouring towns.  She takes cash sales from retail and wholesale customers whos generally come from large towns.The group members aim each to generate profits of 19,000 to 41,000 FCFA from the sales of their goods, and will use to repay the loan interest and to see to their families' everyday needs.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and small tools

loans.name: Sharafat

texts.en:
Sharafat is an honest and hardworking wife. She is the loving mother of three girls. Since childhood Sharafat has been interested in business. For 15 years Sharafat has been running her fabric business. Her older daughter helps her with it. Sharafat wants to provide for her children’s needs. Sharafat has requested a loan of 13,000 TJS to purchase woman’s fabric, food and clothes. Sharafat is thankful to the lenders who support her.      

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase two calves and one cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase three young cattle and fodder

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Nana Ama

texts.en: Nana is a fish monger in Elmina, a fishing community on Cape Coast. She is married and has six dependants. Her husband is a farmer. She helps to pay the utility bills and other household expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to continue to buy more fresh fish to sell. In the photo, she is standing by the traditionally-built oven she uses to smoke the fish.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale.

loans.name: Phelesiah

texts.en:
Phelesiah is a 33-year-old businesswoman, mother and wife to Charles who is also a businessman. They have three children, aged between seven and ten years old, and reside in the Kwisero area of the larger Kakamega County.

She sells grains, mostly maize, because of its high demand in this part of Kenya. She has been doing this business for the last 12 years and is able to make a monthly income of KES. 9,500. She has been awarded a second loan of KES. 20,000 from KADET LTD which she will use to buy five bags of maize for resale.

She intends to use the profit to invest back into her business and also pay back her loan without default. Her dream is to open a grain shop as opposed to her current business location, which is an open air stall.

loans.use: to buy five bags of grain.

loans.name: Badenyaton I Group

texts.fr:
BADENYATON I est un regroupe de femmes mariées du village de  BIMAWERE dans la préfecture de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide, du gombo, du bisaps. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe BADENYATON I ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
DJENEBA, assise avec un petit seau en main, compte utiliser  son  prêt actuel pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, payer les frais de labour et sarclage,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles pour la culture, au grand marché de Kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 21000 à 23000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
BADENYATON I is a group of married women from the village of BIMAWERE, in the prefecture of SAN, Region of SÉGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in traditional families, and they average 42 years of age and have at least six children. The group members grow peanuts, okra, and hibiscus flowers. 

Concerned about making their plantations profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. After having properly repaid the previous loan, they are now on their second farm loan.

DJENEBA, who is seated in the photo and holding a small pail, intends to use her loan to pay for plowing and weeding and to buy a sufficient amount of peanut seeds, sundry supplies and equipment, and some inputs for farming. These items are purchased at the main market of Kimparana City. Following the off-season, the harvested crops are stocked for a certain time, so that they gain value. And then they are sold retail (and often in bulk) and for cash at the main market of Kimparana and at surrounding markets. The customers generally come from large cities.

After selling the produce, the group members each plan on making a profit of 21,000 to 23,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest and for covering typical family expenses.

loans.use: to pay for labor and to buy farm inputs, seeds, and tools

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba is married and has three children. Her husband is a mason. Aba smokes fish for sale at Elmina, which she has done for five years. Aba assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Aba will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to smoke for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more fresh fish to smoke for sale.

loans.name: Badenyaton Ii Group

texts.fr:
BADENYATON II est un regroupe de femmes mariées du village de  BIMAWERE dans la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 37  ans, au moins 6 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide du gombo, du bisaps etc. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe BADENYATON II ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
SALI, qui est debout, troisième à droite la main sur la tête de l’enfant,  compte utiliser le prêt actuel pour acheter, des semences d’arachide,  payer les frais de labour et sarclage,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles pour la culture, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 19500 à 22000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
BADENYATON II is a group of married women from the village of BIMAWERE, in the prefecture of SAN, Region of SÉGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in traditional families, and they average 37 years of age and have at least six children. The group members grow peanuts, okra, and hibiscus flowers, etc.

Concerned about making their plantations profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. After having properly repaid their previous loans, they are now on their second farm loan.

SALI, who is standing third from the right in the photo with her hand placed on her child’s head, intends to use the current loan to pay for plowing and weeding and to buy a sufficient amount of peanut seeds, sundry supplies and equipment, and some inputs for farming. These items are purchased at the main market of Kimparana. 

After wintertime, the harvested crops are stocked for a certain time, so that they gain value. And then they are sold retail (and often in bulk) and for cash at the main market of Kimparana and at surrounding markets. The customers generally come from large cities.

After selling the produce, the group members each plan on making a profit of 19,500 to 22,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest and for covering typical family expenses.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs, seeds, and tools and to pay for labor

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua sells gari, fresh tomatoes, oil and other food items. She also sells secondhand cloths at Elmina. She is married to a farmer and together they take care of their five dependants. Her income is used to help in the payment of utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy food items to sell. She hopes to plough back her additional profit into the business.

loans.use: to buy food items to sell.

loans.name: Damirbek's Group

texts.en:
Damirbek is a member of this group. He is 31 and married. Together with his wife, he raises his daughter and son. Damirbek works as a loan officer in the financial group “Kompanion.” 

In addition to his job, he also sells foodstuffs to make additional money to meet the family needs. He started this business a year ago with an initial investment of 30 000 soms. He earns an additional 4200 soms per month for this business. 

With the money received from the loan, Damirbek wants to purchase more foodstuffs for resale. In the future he wants to purchase a vehicle with the money gained from the business, and will try to help his brother finish building his house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase foodstuffs.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 39. He and his wife Nancy are from the Kwisero area of Kakamega County and have three children between the ages of twelve and eight. 

Vincent operates a small retail shop selling basic household items like sugar, cooking fat, and detergents. He has been engaged in this business for the last two years and makes a monthly income of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). He is taking his second loan from KADET Ltd. which he intends to use to buy some stock for his retail shop, mostly foodstuffs. 

Nancy is also engaged in business. 

Vincent will use the profits to pay back his loan. His dream is to open a wholesale shop where he can stock a variety of household items. He is therefore looking for a Kiva lender to help him realize this dream.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for his kiosk

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 28 years old, married to Linet, and together they are blessed with one child. He sells African handicrafts which he has been doing for the last four years. The business earns him a monthly income of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). 

This is his first loan from KADET Ltd. He will use the loan funds to buy more handicrafts for sale. Peter hopes to educate his child and be a successful businessman by joining international exporters in the future.

loans.use: To buy handicrafts for sale

loans.name: Sabougnouma 1 Group

texts.fr:
SABOUGNOUMA 1 est un regroupe de femmes mariées du village de  KIFOKAN dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 41 ans et au moins 8 enfants.
Elles cultivent  du fonio du haricot et du gombo. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  le  prêt précédent, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
KADIA, la troisième debout à gauche avec un foulard blanc sur la tête, compte utiliser  le  prêt actuel pour acheter, des semence de fonio les frais de labour et sarclage  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles pour la culture, au grand marché de kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 15000 à 17000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
SABOUGNOUMA 1 is a group of married women from the village of KIFOKAN in the prefecture of SAN, region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They average 41 years of age and have at least eight children each.

They grow fonio, beans and okra. In order to make their farming activities profitable, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organization two years ago. Having correctly repaid their first loan, they are now seeking a second one. 

KADIA, standing third from the left with a white scarf wrapped around her head, plans to use this loan to buy fonio seeds, to pay for the cost of plowing and weeding, and to buy small farming equipment and agricultural inputs. She will make her purchases at the grand market of Kimparana. After the rainy season, the crops will be stored for a while to increase in value prior to being sold for cash at the Kimparana market and surrounding markets, at retail (often wholesale), to customers who typically come from large cities.

Once their products are sold, the group members expect to earn a profit ranging between 15,000 to 17,000 FCFA each, which they will use to pay the interest on the loan and to cover recurring household expenses.

loans.use: to buy inputs, seeds, and small farming equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more sheep and fodder.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua is married and has five dependants. Her husband is a fisherman.

For the past twenty years, Efua has been living on the income made from the sale of smoked fish. She responsibly assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan of 600 GHS will be used to buy additional fresh fish to smoke and so improve her business.

She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards the university education of her dependents.

loans.use: to buy additional fish to smoke.

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame has two children, and her husband is a driver. The family lives in Elmina.

For the past ten years Maame has been selling bread as well as porridge she has made from millet. She helps to pay the utility bills and other household expenses.

Maame’s loan will be used to buy sugar, millet, flour and other things to prepare her porridge for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy sugar, millet, flour and other things to prepare her porridge for sale.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Née vers 1957 à Souloukoro,  Madame Aminata est une femme mariée, mère de 8 enfants, qui vit dans une famille  polygame dans le quartier Kouloukoro  de la ville  de Koutiala. 
N’ayant pas eu la chance de continuer les études, très tôt elle s’intéressa aux activités commerciales notamment à l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires  et bien d’autres articles divers. Nantie d’une douzaine expérience dans ses  activités de vente de condiments et d’articles divers, elle est très sollicitée et appréciée. 
Pour pouvoir combattre les petites ruptures qu’elle subit et qui lui fait perdre de la clientèle, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle  il y a 7 ans.  Après 8 prêts   solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous correctement  remboursés, elle est à son 4eme prêt  individuel dont les précédents ont été bien remboursés.  
Elle compte acheter, 4 sacs de 25 kg d’oignon, 3 cartons de savons traditionnels, une douzaine de paires de sandales et une demi douzaine de perles pour la ceinture. 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Koutiala et effectue sa vente  au marché  de Kouloukoro,  à une clientèle constituée essentiellement de femmes, en détail et  au comptant. 
Avec le renforcement de son fonds de commerce, elle espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 105.000FCFA  par mois  qu’elle envisage utiliser  pour payer les  intérêts du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso,  participer aux dépenses familiales et s’entretenir elle même ainsi que ses enfants. 
Madame Aminata compte toujours sur les financements de Soro Yiriwaso  pour être grossiste de condiments au grand marché de Koutiala.
texts.en:
Born around 1957 in Souloukoro, Mrs. Aminata is a married woman and a mother of eight. She lives in a polygamous family in the Kouloukoro neighborhood in the city of Koutiala.
Not having had the opportunity to study, she got interested in commercial activities at a very early age, notably buying and purchasing condiments and many other miscellaneous articles. Thanks to a dozen years of experience selling condiments and miscellaneous articles, she is very much in demand and appreciated.
Seven years ago, to fight small product shortages she experienced and which caused her to lose some of her customers, she decided to join Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance organization to increase her customer satisfaction. After eight solidarity loans (group loans), all of which were successfully repaid, she is now in her fourth individual loan; previous loans have been successfully repaid.
She intends on purchasing four bags of onions, three packages of soap and many other small articles with this loan. She gets her supplies from Koutiala's great market and retails cash at the market in Kouloukoro, to a clientele mainly composed of women.
By strengthening her commercial interests, she hopes to make an average monthly profit of 105,000 FCFA, which she is planning on using to repay Soro's loan interests, to participate to the family's expenses, and to support herself and her children. Mrs. Aminata still counts on Soro Yiriwaso's funding to be a condiment wholesaler at the great market in Koutiala.

loans.use: purchase of various products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase new mobile phones and prepaid telephone cards

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en:
Reuben, a modest and hardworking 44-year-old from Kakamega County, Western Kenya, is married to Beatrice and they have three children between the ages of 10 and 20. Reuben runs an open-air stall selling household items such as washing basins, water taps, charcoal stoves, water drums and many other household items demanded by his clientele. In this business for the last 18 years, he earns a monthly income of Kshs 17,500.

Now requesting his sixth loan of Kshs 65,000 from Kadet Ltd, Reuben will use the money to purchase more household items to sell and will reinvest the profits into his business and repay his loan. His dream is to open a shop where he can sell from a closed rather than an open-air environment.

loans.use: to buy household products to sell.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa is married and takes care of six dependents. Her husband is a fisherman. 

For the past three years Adjoa has been selling cosmetics. On her lap are some of the cosmetics which she sells by moving from one area to another. Adjoa  uses her income to see to the upkeep of her home. 

Adjoa is going to use her 800 GHS loan to purchase more cosmetics to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, She plans to build a cosmetics shop.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam est âgée de 54 ans, mariée et mère de 7 enfants. Elle vit  avec son mari, sa coépouse et  leurs enfants  dans le quartier Sogomougou  de la ville de Koutiala.  
Du à des problèmes de famille, Mariam n’as pas pu  continuer les études,  raison pour laquelle elle s’est tôt intéressée au commerce auprès de sa maman, depuis le bas.  Après avoir mené plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus, finalement elle opta pour l’achat vente de  l’arachide depuis maintenant  20 ans.  
Afin d’augmenter son fonds de commerce et d’élargir son activité, Mariam  a fait recours  à l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 7 ans.   Elle a pris 13 prêts dans l’association (prêt solidaire) tous remboursés correctement  et elle est à son premier prêt individuel. Avec ce financement, elle compte acheter, 10 sacs d’arachides  auprès des stockeurs  de céréales de Koutiala  et effectue sa vente au grand marché à une clientèle composée  de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant et très généralement en détail.  Avec ce financement, elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 80.000FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts de Soro et contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Ms. Mariam is 54 years old, married, and the mother of seven children. She lives with her husband, her co-wife, and their children in the Sogomougou district of Koutiala City.  Due to family problems, Mariam could not continue with her schooling, which is why she soon became interested  in commerce at an early age, along side her mom. After having run several revenue-generating businesses, she opted in the end to buy and sell peanuts and has been doing so for twenty years now. 

In order to increase her working capital and to expand her business, Mariam turned toward the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso seven years ago. She took out thirteen loans with the association (solidarity loans) that were all properly repaid. She is now on her first individual loan. With this financing, she intends to buy 10 sacks of peanuts from grain stockers of Koutiala and to make her sales at the main market. Her  customer base is composed of women and men. Sales are made in cash and generally at the retail level. 

She plans on a monthly profit of 80,000 francs CFA that she envisions using for repaying the interest on the Soro loan and improving her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to buy sacks of peanuts

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua is a widow and has six dependents. She makes banku and smokes fish to sell in Elmina. She also sees to the upkeep of her home. 

Efua’s loan will be used to buy fresh fish to smoke for sale. She hopes to reinvest her new profits. 

In this picture, Efua is standing by the traditionally-built oven in which she smokes the fish.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish to smoke.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence, 35, is a single mother of three children. She has been operating a grocery store for the past three years. The business earns her a monthly income of 30,000 KES.

This is Florence’s second loan with KADET LTD; she successfully managed to pay off her previous loan. She will use the loan amount to buy ten sacks of tomatoes, five sacks of onions, ten sacks of potatoes and one sack of cabbages for sale.

Florence intends to use the anticipated profits to educate her children and hopes to supply groceries to big hotels in the future.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, onions, cabbages and potatoes for sale

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua, married with seven dependents, has been a fishmonger and a chop bar operator in Elmina for 20 years. She cooks foods such as banku, fufu, rice-balls, etc. Her income helps to pay the utility bills and school fees.

Ekua will use the loan to purchase fish, maize, cassava, plantain and other ingredients to cook for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to further her children's education. The photo shows her standing close to the oven she uses for the fish.

loans.use: to purchase fish, maize, cassava, plantain and other ingredients to cook for sale.

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame, who is married to a fisherman, has eight dependents. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home and also sells boodo, a local baked dish made from flour, sugar, maize and other ingredients in Elmina, a fishing community in Cape Coast.

Maame will use the loan to purchase maize, flour and sugar, and plans to put the new profits from her expanded business toward the acquisition of some land. In the photo, Maame is shown squatting close to the oven she uses to cook her product.

loans.use: to purchase maize, flour and sugar.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua sells boodo — a local, baked dish made from flour, sugar, maize and other ingredients — at Ankwanda near Elmina. She is married and has five dependants. Her husband is a fisherman. Efua has been selling boodo, for 10 years. She supports her husband in providing for the daily needs of the family. Her loan will be used to buy flour, suagr, and maize. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy flour, suagr, and maize.

loans.name: Sayohatkhon

texts.en:
Sayohatkhon is a hard-working woman and the mother of one child. She in engaged in tailoring. Sayohatkhon sews blinds and dresses that she hands out to her relatives to sell at the market. Sayohatkhon has been running this business for 11 years. Once a week she purchases fabrics and sews blinds and dresses at home. She would like a loan of 7,500 TJS to purchase fabrics and expand her business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy fabrics and expand her business

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba sells Fante kenkey at Elmina. Fante Kenkey — fermented mailze or casava wrapped in dried plantain leaves — is very common amongst the people in the Central Region of Ghana. Aba is married and has six dependants. Her husband is a fisherman. Aba has been selling Fante Kenkey for 9 years. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy bags of maize. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy bags of maize.

loans.name: Hagar

texts.en: Hagar has four children and a junior-high level of education. She cooks food such as "fufu" which is made from cassava, "banku" from corn, and other dishes for sale at Elmina, which she has done for three years. Her husband is a farmer. Hagar uses her income to assist her husband pay utility bills and other household expenses. She will use the loan to purchase food items such as cassava, plantain, and maize to cook dishes for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Hagar plans to build a restaurant one day.

loans.use: to purchase food items such as cassava, plantain, maize to cook for sale.

loans.name: Nyame

texts.en: Nyame is married and has six dependants. Her husband is a farmer. She cooks food such as "fufu" with palmnut soup and "banku" with okra soup.  She has been in the food business for 10 years and uses her income to assist her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Nyame will use the loan to purchase food items to cook for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Nyame plans to build a food stall.

loans.use: to purchase food items to cook for sale.

loans.name: Guram

texts.en:
Guram is a 56-year-old farmer from the village of Tskhratskharo in West Georgia. He is married and lives with his wife Marine and their 13-year-old daughter, who goes to school. 

The only source of income for Guram's family is agriculture. They have three milk cows, the milk of which is used for cheese production. The cheese they produce, approximately 20 kg per week, is sold at the local open market by Guram and Marine. Along with the dairy farm they also have a half-hectare plot of land, which is used for growing wheat. Any corn they grow is mainly used for feeding the cows. 

With the loan Guram plans to purchase an additional half hectare of land, which will be used for the same purpose: growing wheat. Additional wheat will be sold at the local market by the family members. It will increase the income of the family. 

An increase in income will allow the family to improve their living conditions as well as invest in expanding the dairy farm by increasing the number of milk cows.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural land

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana is a widow and has four children. She has received a senior high school education. Nana sells ice creams, bags of water and other items at Elmina, which she has done for three years. Her income is used to educate, feed, and cloth her children. Nana will use the loan to purchase ice cream and bags of water to sale. With her profits from her expanded business, Nana plans to buy a bigger refrigerator.

loans.use: to purchase ice creams and bags of water to sale.

loans.name: Chingiz

texts.en:
Chingiz is married and has 3 children. He is 41 years old. Chingiz needs 2000 AZN to buy spare parts for his car. 
Chingiz lives in Absheron region with his wife and 3 children. He learned this business from his friend who has a taxi too. , Chingiz has been working in the Taxi business for the last 9 years.

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua, the mother of one child, is married to a fisherman and has been making doughnuts and meat pies in Elmina for the past three years. Efua uses her income to pay the utility bills and other household expenses and will use the loan to purchase flour, sugar, oil, salt and other ingredients. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save towards her child's education.

loans.use: to purchase flour, sugar, oil, salt and other ingredients.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua is a single parent taking care of five dependents. For the past four years she has sold wakye, a dish made mainly of rice and beans cooked together, in Elmina. Efua uses her income to see to the upkeep of her home.

Efua will use her loan of 800 GHS to purchase beans (as seen in the picture), oil, pepper, tomatoes, rice and other foodstuffs to enable her to cook more for sale.

With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to build a restaurant.

loans.use: to buy the ingredients to make wakye to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy five bags of maize to resell.

loans.name: Yasha

texts.en: Yasha is engaged in an agricultural business. He keeps livestock and has agro machinery. Agriculture is the family’s main source of income, but it is not enough to cover the Yasha family’s daily costs. With the requested loan he plans to increase livestock, develop agriculture further, and increase income. Yasha is desperate to improve the living conditions of his family. He lives together with his wife and son.

loans.use: to pay for livestock.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba is married to a farmer, and together they have three children. Aba has been through junior high school.

Aba sells cosmetics, earrings, panties and so forth at Ankwanda village near Elmina. Her business is just two years old.

Aba wants to increase the volume of goods sold. A loan is going to help her buy more cosmetics for resale. Aba anticipates reinvesting new profits in her business.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson, 36, is married to Rose; they are blessed with three children aged nine, seven and five years old. For the past ten years Nelson has been a crop farmer. The business earns him a monthly income of 18,500 KES.

This is Nelson’s third loan from KADET LTD; he has successfully managed to pay off his previous loans. He will use the funds to buy twenty piglets, pig feed, and also to dig a well.

Nelson will use the anticipated profits to buy another donkey to supply water to his neighborhood. He hopes to educate his children as well as operate a large-scale pork operation to supply big hotels in the country.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed and to dig a well.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa is married and has five dependents. Her husband is a farmer. As part of her responsibilities she helps to pay school fees and utility bills.

For the past ten years Adjoa has sold fruit such as pineapples, oranges, pawpaw and others in Elmina. Her 800 GHS loan will be used to buy fruit to sell. She hopes to reinvest all new profits in her business.

loans.use: to buy fruit to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy lubricants.

loans.name: Mena

texts.en:
Mena is married and has three children. Her husband works with Zoom Lion Company, a waste management company. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. 

Mena sells gari, detergent, sugar, rice and other items in both small and large quantities in Elmina. Her loan will be used to buy more gari, Omo-brand detergent, rice and other items. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a shop.

loans.use: to buy gari, Omo-brand detergent, rice and other items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy powdered milk

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica makes a living by producing and selling palm oil. She also has a side business selling fish and has completed a senior high school level of education. She is divorced and the sole means of support for six dependents. She has wanted to expand her business for years and is applying for this loan from Kiva to buy more palm fruit to turn into oil. She will use the additional income made possible by this loan to expand her business and to try to set money aside for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy more palm fruit to process into oil for sale.

loans.name: Artur

texts.en: Artur is engaged in an agricultural business. He keeps livestock and has agro machinery. Agriculture is the family’s main source of income, but it is not enough to cover their daily costs. Artur would like to increase his number of livestock and develop his business further. Artur dreams of improving his household conditions and provide necessary education for his growing children. Artur lives with his wife and two little children.

loans.use: to pay for livestock.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua makes a living by selling gari (or cassava flour) in the town of Elmina. She has been educated through junior high school, is married and has two children. Her husband is a teacher. She works hard to help her husband pay school fees and utility bills. She will use this loan to buy cassava to make more gari to sell to her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to complete building a home for her family.

loans.use: to buy cassava to turn into flour for sale.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 41 years old, married and has two children. He runs a general store where he sells goods to people who live in his town. He has owned his store for 10 years and makes an income of KES. 20,000 a month. He plans to use this loan to buy more sugar, wheat and maize flour to sell to his customers. This will be his second loan from KADET LTD, where he has been a good client who made payments on time. In the future, James plans to open a second store and, eventually, a supermarket. James describes himself as hard working.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, wheat and maize flour for his general store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy inputs and agricultural seeds.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more meat to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Josef

texts.en:
Josef comes from village Meore Sviri, West Georgia. He lives in the village with his wife Marina and three children – 15- and 14-year-old daughters and a 12-year-old son. All three children go to school. 

Josef and Marina run agricultural business of the family, which is their only source of income. They have two milk cows and sell approximately 15 kg of cheese per week on the local open market. Also the family has 0.8 ha of vineyard with 1000 grape vines. Harvested grapes are sold on the local open market by Josef. Along with the above-mentioned, Josef and Marina grow cucumbers and potatoes on their own plot of land. Vegetables are sold on the local open market as well. 

With the requested credit Josef will hire a tractor for tilling part of the plot. He will sow greens, which are highly demanded on the local market. Sales of greens will increase the income of the family. They plan to reinvest the full amount of the received profit from greens in the same business. The development of the greens business will increase the income of the family over the long term.

loans.use: to purchase fuel for the tractor and seeds for greens.

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en: Larisa is engaged in agriculture. She grows vegetables in a greenhouse. The client needs financial means to renovate the conservatory, as it is old and doesn’t serve its purpose any more. The greenhouse renovation and the effort to increase it to the standards will allow Larisa to increase her income and improve her family’s living conditions. She lives together with her husband and her son, who helps her run the business.

loans.use: to pay for renovating the greenhouse

loans.name: Bibi

texts.en: Bibi is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house, but it has neither electricity nor piped-in water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. For the past 10 years, she has made a living by selling coconuts in a local market and to her neighbors. She faces a big challenge because of the high cost of transportation from rural areas to urban areas. She dreams of expanding her business and serving a large market  in the future. She is applying for a loan for KES. 10,000 to buy sacks of mangoes and coconuts to resell. She decided to join Yehu to get loans and boost her business.

loans.use: buy sacks of mangoes and coconuts to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is 33 years old, married, and she and her husband have three children. She has been practicing  mixed farming. She has been doing this for the last eight  years. 

She learned about KADET LTD through marketing done by the KADET staff within Narok Town. She is a good client and this is her first loan which she is planning to use to expand her business. She hopes to use the profit from this loan to reinvest back into her business. 

Her hope and dream is to become a great business lady. She is an energetic lady who is dedicated to her work and who can do more if supported financially.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel, aged 33, is married to Carolyne who is a teacher and they are blessed with one child. Samuel sells fruit wholesale which he has been doing for eight years.The business earns him a monthly income of KES 8,000.

This is his first loan with KADET LTD. He will use it to buy fruit, e.g., apples, grapes, and mangoes for resale. Samuel intends to use the anticipated profits to educate his children and hopes to supply fruit to all parts of the country using a truck in future.

loans.use: To buy fruit such as apples, grapes, tangerines, etc., for sale.

loans.name: Phoebe

texts.en:
Phoebe is a married woman who lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past 6 years, Phoebe has operated a retail shop, selling to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenge is the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of opening another business in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking oil, and detergents for her store. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking oil and detergents to sell.

loans.name: Maka

texts.en:
Maka is a 28-year-old farmer from village Kvaliti, in the western part of the country. She is married and lives with her husband, Mamuka. Mamuka works in a local manganese producing company as a laborer. He also assists his wife in farming activities. The family owns 1700 grape vines and sells harvested grapes. Also they have 0.7 ha of agricultural land, where different vegetables are grown. Harvest is sold on the local open market. 

With the requested credit Maka plans purchase a milk cow. She will produce cheese and sell it on the open market along with harvested vegetables. It will positively influence the income of the family. Maka believes that their small dairy farm will be successful and increase the income of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives at a family house that has neither  electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past 6 years, Mariam has operated a potato-selling business, selling from home to her neighbours. Mariam's major challenge is seasonality in her business. She dreams of opening another business in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of potatoes and wheat flour to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of potatoes and wheat flour.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farming supplies

loans.name: Nabil

texts.en:
Nabil is a 59-year-old hard-working man who has been always fascinated with stones and rock and the way they are shaped.

Since he was in his twenties, he has been sculpturing rocks as a hobby but then he left his full-time job and dedicated his time to being a sculptor. Nabil makes a lot of amazingly beautiful sculptures such as Petra drawings out of rocks and stone with his hands using few tools. He also makes building entrance decoration by sculpturing on the wall.

Now Nabil is applying for a loan to buy electrical tools for sculpturing that would save him time and effort when creating an artistic piece like the one he is holding in the picture.

loans.use: To buy electrical tools for sculpturing.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a married woman with three children all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent. For the past three months Alice has operated a potato-selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Alice faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future. 

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of potatoes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of potatoes for sale.

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
A sus 69 años Oscar es un luchador que debido a la falta de oportunidades laborales para las personas de su edad, y con la ilusión de mejorar su calidad de vida, decidió comenzar con su propio negocio, donde vende productos de uso personal puerta a puerta, trabaja todos los días ofreciendo estos productos y cobrando a sus clientes cuentas pendientes.
 
Actualmente Oscar vive con su hermana por quien responde económicamente, lo que lo ha motivado a salir adelante y estar en pro de brindarle a su hermana una mejor calidad de vida, sin embargo hoy en día Oscar solicita un préstamo que le permita surtir su negocio generosamente y así no sólo atraer más clientes gracias a la cantidad, y variedad de productos si no también que lo diferencie de otros vendedores que hay en el sector gracias a la calidad en el servicio.
texts.en:
At the age of 69, Oscar is a tenacious man who, due to the lack of employment opportunities for people of his age and wanting to improve his quality of life, decided to start his own business selling personal use items door to door.  He works every day selling these products and collecting pending payments from customers.

Currently, Oscar is living with his sister who depends on him economically.  What has motivated him to get ahead is providing his sister with a better quality of life.  However, today Oscar is asking for a loan that will make it possible for him to generously stock his business in order not only to attract customers with the quantity and variety of products but also to stand out from the other vendors in the sector thanks to the quality of service.

loans.use: to buy ample amounts of stock merchandise.

loans.name: Kerenke

texts.en: Kerenke grows wheat and is also a livestock trader. He lives with his wife and their two children. Kerenke is seeking a loan from KADET to buy farm supplies and more livestock as he doesn’t have enough money to do this. This would be a big help and allow him to expand his business by increasing the number of animals he possesses. His goal is to work hard to support his family and, above all, to help his children complete their education.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and more livestock

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana, aged 32, is a single mother of one child. She has been selling clothes door-to-door for three years. The business earns her a monthly income of KES 25,000.

This is Juliana's first loan from KADET LTD. She will use the funds to buy more clothes for resale. Juliana intends to use the anticipated profits to educate her child and hopes to have a classic boutique in the future.

loans.use: To buy clothes for sale

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en:
Agatha is a married woman with 2 children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

For the past 3 years, Agatha has operated a clothing sales business, selling in a shop to her neighbors and passersby. Her greatest monthly expense is the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of opening another business in the future. Agatha plans to use this KES 20,000 loan to purchase bundles of clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Mkwenye

texts.en:
Mkwenye is a 33-year-old married man and father of four children. He has been  practising crop farming in Narok. Mkwenye is requesting a loan for the third time from KADET in order to buy fertilizer and prepare the land, both necessary means to support his main source of earning a living.

Mkwenye hopes to improve his business by expanding his crop production's variety, quality and quantity. He is a hardworking man who can do more if funded.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and prepare the land

loans.name: Sandra Mirtha

texts.es: La Señora Sandra, oriunda villa verde de Cochabamba, su actividad es una tienda de abarrotes ubicado en el torno en su propio domicilio, La Sra. Sandra saco este crédito para el incremento de capital comprando mercadería para su tienda y surtirla, su negocio es grande y esta en plena avenida, con el tiempo ella  quiere llegar a tener su almacén donde pueda ofrecer todo tipo de mercadería para así satisfacer a los clientes,  es una persona  trabajadora que sabe que con esmero, voluntad y trabajo podrá salir adelante, agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: Sandra is from Villa Verde in Cochabamba.  She has a grocery store located at her address.  Sandra took out this loan to increase capital buying merchandise to stock her store.  Her store is large and located right on the avenue.  In time, she’d like to get her store to the point where she can stock all kinds of merchandise to satisfy her customers.  She is a hard working person who knows that with dedication, will and work she can get ahead.  She’s grateful to the institution for the support provided.

loans.use: to buy stock grocery items for her store.

loans.name: Naira

texts.en:
Naira is a farmer from a small village in Sachkhere District, West Georgia. She is 44 years old, married and lives with her husband Josef, their 16-year-old daughter and 13-year-old son. Both of the children go to school. Josef is a constructor and works in his and nearby villages when there are orders from villagers. But the major source of income for the family is their vineyard and nut growing – the family has 800 grape vines, used for wine and vodka production. Both of the drinks are sold locally. Also they have nine nut trees and sell approximately 150 kg of nuts in the season. Total average monthly income for the family is approximately 400 Laris. 

With the requested credit Naira plans to purchase a milk cow. She will use the milk for cheese production and sell the cheese together with wine and nuts on the local market. 

Purchase of a cow and the sale of cheese will increase the income of the family. This will allow them to purchase new household goods and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow.

loans.name: Baraka Office Group

texts.fr: La cliente Bauma représentante du groupe d’affaire « Baraka office »,  est entrepreneur, âgée de 42 ans, mariée, mère de 4 enfants, tous étudient. Son mari est un activiste de droits de l’homme dans la ville de Goma au sein d’une organisation non gouvernementale. Elle est vendeuse de pommes de terre, bananes, huile raffiné, huile de palme, etc., au petit  marché sectoriel de l’office.  Il ya 7 ans révolus qu’elle exerce cette activité. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  16 cycles avec le crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner  avec  4 sacs de pommes de terre, 5 régimes de bananes, 2 bidons d’huile Rina, 1fus d’huile de palme, etc.  En plus, elle ambitionne scolariser ses enfants et construire une maison étant donné qu’elle est encore locataire.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire «  Baraka Office» est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en:
The client named Bauma, the representative of the business group called « Baraka Office », is an entrepreneur of 42, married and the mother of four children, all enrolled in school. Her husband is a human rights activist in the town of Goma, working for an NGO. Bauma sells pototoes, bananas, refined oil, palm oil, and so on at the the Office's small sector market. She has been in this work for a full seven years, but she has just finished repaying her 16th loan with Hekima. 

This new loan will allow her to buy four sacks of potatoes, five stalks of bananas, two jerrycans of Rina oil, and one barrel of palm oil, etc. Morever, she would like to pay her children's school fees and build a house, since she is presently renting. This client thanks Hekima for working on behalf of poor women who are excluded from conventional banks. Please note that the business group «  Baraka Office» is made up mainly of women.

loans.use: to buy four sacks of potatoes, five stalks of bananas, two jerrycans of Rina oil, and one barrel of palm oil, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Taatai

texts.en:
Taatai is 30 years old, single and living with his parents. He plans to use this loan to purchase raw materials for his maize crops and to hire workers. He hopes this will improve his maize production for the upcoming harvest.

Taatai hopes to earn the necessary income to ensure his well-being and that of his parents and to continue making headway as a maize producer. This is his third loan with KADET LTD. He has not had previous loans with any other MFIs.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for his maize crops and to hire workers.

loans.name: Eliana Cinthya

texts.es:
Eliana, es socia del Banco Comunal Emprendedoras, tiene 20 años es madre soltera y tiene una hija de un año. Se dedica a la venta de ropa para damas caballeros y niños. Eliana atiende pedidos de amigos y familiares, los días domingos viaja a la feria de Huanta, gracias a Dios le va bien. El préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de ropa para surtir su mercadería.
Eliana está en FINCA Perú hace 2 años, le gusta las reuniones de su Banco Comunal por la facilidad en las que recibe los préstamos y por las capacitaciones que recibe, le enseñan a trabajar y a valorarse como mujer. Su sueño es poder abrir una tienda grande ropa.
texts.en:
Eliana is a member of the “Emprendedoras” communal bank.  She’s 20 years old and a single mother of a one-year-old daughter.  She sells clothes for women, men and children.  She fills orders from friends and family members.  On Sundays she goes to the Huanta farmers market and thank God is doing well.  The loan will be used to buy clothes to stock her business.

Eliana has been in FINCA Perú for two years.  She likes her communal bank meetings because of the loan terms she gets and because of the training she receives; they teach her how to work and value herself as a woman.  Her dream is to be able to open a big clothing store.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Victor Hugo

texts.es: El señor Víctor es artesano de zapatos de cholita su taller es en su mismo domicilio realiza los zapatos y después lo comercializa  en la feria 16 de julio los jueves y domingo ya esta con ese trabajo mas de 10 años tiene mucha experiencia  también tiene empleados que dependen de su trabajo solicito el crédito para mas material  por que le llegaron contratos para las fiestas de 16 julio y agosto    es cliente nuevo  vive en el alto por la zona alto lima en  domicilio  propio, es una persona muy amigable tiene muchos clientes por el buen trabajo que realiza, esta agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Víctor is an artisanal “cholita” (indigenous woman) shoe maker; his shop is in his home.  He makes the shoes and then sells them at the Thursday and Sunday 16 de Julio market.  He’s been in this line of work for over 10 years and has much experience.  He also has employees that depend on his work.  He requested the loan for more materials because he’s gotten contracts for the July 16th and August holidays.  

He is a new client.  He lives in his own house located in El Alto’s Alto Lima sector.  He is a very friendly person and has many customers thanks to the good work he does.  He’s grateful to the institution for the support provided.

loans.use: to buy artisanal shoe making supplies.

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en:
Gifty sells boodo and local meat pies in Elmina. Boodo is a local baked dish made from flour, sugar, maize and other ingredients. Gifty's loan will be used to buy flour, sugar and other ingredients. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy land.

Gifty is married and is responsible by helping to pay the household expenses. She has been through junior high school. At the time of this visit, Gifty had arranged some of the boodo in the traditionally built oven and so could not show us how it looked.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar and other ingredients to make boodo

loans.name: Juana Felicitas

texts.es: Juana Felicitas, es socia del Banco Comunal Emprendedoras, tiene 62 años es casada y tiene 7 hijos. Se dedica a la venta D. comida, el préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra D. abarrotes para la preparación D. alimentos. Juana tiene un puesto D. venta D. comida en el mercado Santa Clara. Le gusta FINCA Perú por sus capacitaciones y porque le dan crédito a base D. confianza, se pueD. ahorrar, con sus ahorros construyó su casa y está educando a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Juana Felicitas is a member of the “Emprendedoras” communal bank.  She’s 62 years old, married and has 7 children.  She sells food.  She will use the loan to buy groceries used to prepare her food.  Juana has a food sales stand in the Santa Clara market.  

She likes FINCA Perú because of the training and because loans are granted based on trust, because one can save.  She used her savings to build her house and is educating her children.

loans.use: to buy stock items at wholesale for her business.

loans.name: Leslia Clarisa

texts.es: Leslia Clarisa tiene 35 años. Es madre soletera con un hijo a su cargo. La actividad económica de Leslia es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 11 años que se dedica a este negocio. Es una mujer muy luchadora y que le gusta su trabajo. La ubicación de su negocio es de manera ambulante, por lo que inicio por cuenta propia y con el apoyo necesario de su familia ha logrado salir adelante. El motivo del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de camisetas, pantalones, bolsos, cosméticos y calzado.
texts.en: Leslia Clarisa is 35 years old.  She’s a single mother with a son in her care.  Leslia’s economic activity is selling general merchandise.  She’s been in this business for over 11 years.  She is a tenacious woman who enjoys her work.  She is a street vendor.  She started out on her own initiative and with the necessary help from her family has managed to get ahead.  The reason for the loan is for working capital: to buy t-shirts, pants, purses, cosmetics and footwear.

loans.use: to buy t-shirts, pants, purses, cosmetics and footwear.

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is a married woman with 2 children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

For the past 4 years, Faith has operated a poultry business, selling from home to her neighbors and those that pass by. Her greatest challenge is the high cost of transportation for the business. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. Faith dreams of expanding her business and operating as a wholesaler in the future. She wants to purchase chicks for her poultry business with the Kshs 20,000.

loans.use: To purchase chicks for her poultry business.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa is divorced and has six dependents. She sells bowls and cooking utensils at Elmina and has done so for 6 years. Adjoa uses her income to see to the upkeep of the home. She will use the loan to purchase bowls and cooking utensils for resale. Adjoa plans to save to build a shop with the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: to purchase bowls and cooking utensils for resale.

loans.name: Kaikai

texts.en:
Kaikai is 28 years old and is married with three children. He resides in Narok Kenya and is a maize farmer. He has been doing maize farming for the past seven years. 

Kaikai knew KADET through a registered client with KADET. Kaikai has been a good client and this is his third loan. He plans to use the loan to prepare land for farming and to buy farm inputs.

He hopes to make a profit and use it to re-invest in other businesses. He is an assiduous man who can do more if funded.

loans.use: to prepare land for farming and to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Winsor

texts.es:
